text:
Hey guys, I’m wondering about the assumption of >2 classes tests such as Kruskal-Walis or ANOVA.

Does those tests assume independent groups, i.e. none of the groups dependent to another? The reason is that I want to compare 3 groups, but 2 of the groups are before and after (i.e. same participants, but observed before and after activity).

If so, is there any alternative for this?

Another question on hypothesis tests, in theory, should the >groups tests be equivalent to multiple binary tests? E.g. ANOVA(group_a, group_b, group_c) == union(ttest(group_a, group_b), ttest(group_b, group_c), ttest(group_a, group_c)). 

Any help would be greatly appreciated!

elements.text:
Hey guys, I’m wondering about the assumption of >2 classes tests such as Kruskal-Walis or ANOVA.

Does those tests assume independent groups, i.e. none of the groups dependent to another? The reason is that I want to compare 3 groups, but 2 of the groups are before and after (i.e. same participants, but observed before and after activity).

If so, is there any alternative for this?

Another question on hypothesis tests, in theory, should the >groups tests be equivalent to multiple binary tests? E.g. ANOVA(group_a, group_b, group_c) == union(ttest(group_a, group_b), ttest(group_b, group_c), ttest(group_a, group_c)). 

Any help would be greatly appreciated!

text:
There's a repeated measures ANOVA, which you can do with my SimpleANOVA.jl package, but the single control(?) group would put a bit of a wrench in that because you wouldn't have a dummy "after" control group. Maybe you could duplicate the control group to make it work, but I don't know how valid that is.

You can do it without repeated measures, though at a cost of less power because you aren't accounting for subject differences.

All else fails, you could do a paired T-test for the two before/after groups and then unpaired T-tests for the remaining pairs, then do a correction for multiple comparisons. But I'm not sure how valid that correction is with mixed types of T-tests.

Does that help?

elements.text:

Maybe you could duplicate the control group to make it work, but I don't know how valid that is.

You can do it without repeated measures, though at a cost of less power because you aren't accounting for subject differences.

All else fails, you could do a paired T-test for the two before/after groups and then unpaired T-tests for the remaining pairs, then do a correction for multiple comparisons. But I'm not sure how valid that correction is with mixed types of T-tests.

Does that help?

text: (Generally speaking, one ANOVA is better than multiple pairwise T-tests even with correction)

elements.text: (Generally speaking, one ANOVA is better than multiple pairwise T-tests even with correction)

text:
<@U01HD5VFXJM> Thanks for your reply! So the standard ANOVA and Kruskal-Walis assumes independent groups, thus, not suitable for my use case?

As for the SimpleANOVA.jl, is there any non-parametric version of that? In my data, I actually need the non-parametric tests since some of my variables is not in normal distribution. I put in ANOVA and T-test as an example only.

elements.text:

text: No worries, but could you confirm if ANOVA and Kruskal-Walis assumes the groups are unpaired? I am just afraid to make a wrong cal here.

elements.text: No worries, but could you confirm if ANOVA and Kruskal-Walis assumes the groups are unpaired? I am just afraid to make a wrong cal here.

text: Basic ANOVA assumes unpaired, repeated measures is needed to pair them.

elements.text: Basic ANOVA assumes unpaired, repeated measures is needed to pair them.

text: I'm not sure the correction procedure but it looks like there's a lot on the web for that.

text: I assumes Kruskal-Walis also the same (since it’s essentially the non-parametric version of that)?

elements.text: I assumes Kruskal-Walis also the same (since it’s essentially the non-parametric version of that)?

text:
As far as I know, the correction is for same groups, but multiple variables (e.g. ttest(group1varA, group2varA), ttest(group1varB, group2varB), etc.), not multiple tests in different groups (e.g. group A vs B with B vs C with A vs C). Cause with the latter, we’ll have 3 p values for each variable. I could be wrong though. Hmm..

If anyone could confirm on that, it would be much appreciated!

elements.text:
As far as I know, the correction is for same groups, but multiple variables (e.g. ttest(group1varA, group2varA), ttest(group1varB, group2varB), etc.), not multiple tests in different groups (e.g. group A vs B with B vs C with A vs C). Cause with the latter, we’ll have 3 p values for each variable. I could be wrong though. Hmm..

If anyone could confirm on that, it would be much appreciated!

text: This should be done in Linear Mixed Models, MixedModels.jl (or R lme4) is better for this. And the assumption with LMMs is constant residual variance, which if that is not satisfied you have to look into GLMMs in lme4 or mixed quantile regression stuff. I think GLMMs in MixedModels.jl are not fully developed, though the package is by the same author (Doug Bates) of lme4

elements.text: This should be done in Linear Mixed Models, MixedModels.jl (or R lme4) is better for this. And the assumption with LMMs is constant residual variance, which if that is not satisfied you have to look into GLMMs in lme4 or mixed quantile regression stuff. I think GLMMs in MixedModels.jl are not fully developed, though the package is by the same author (Doug Bates) of lme4

text: Normality of errors is not really a required assumption either, but the homoscedasticity is

elements.text: Normality of errors is not really a required assumption either, but the homoscedasticity is
